messageBody:
Hi Marvin,

Interesting conversation!

On 9/17/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@...> wrote:
>
> In other words, I don't want to "throw out" an OOP inheritance
> solution just because it also includes notating a method with "test".


Annotations don't hinder your capacity to apply OO principles. Actually,
they give you more flexibility since you are now free to extend a class of
your choice, and also to name your methods any way you want.

> It is better in this case, because munging your method names sothat a tool
> > can pick them off is clearly better addressed with annotations.
>
> MDT ---> Cedric - I do (respectfully) disagree with you on this
> point. The term "optimization for code completion" attempts to
> capture the notion that naming of Classes and Methods can be done in
> a manner that provides more (immediate) clarity within an IDE
> context.
>
> In an earlier post - you referred to it as adding "adding metadata
> to that method" name. In addition to code completion, having all
> like method names begin with a prescribed verb is useful for sorting
> methods.


I agree. Code completion is one of the main reasons why I enforce strictly
the get/set convention throughout my code and everyone around me.

You are right that currently, code completion hasn't been extended to
annotations, so the "test" prefix is more convenient. I believe it's just a
matter of time before IDE's catch up on that level, though, and as a matter
of fact, Eclipse has been supporting categories since
3.2<http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/R-3.2-200606291905/new_noteworthy/eclipse-news-part2.html>(JavaDoc
tags you put on top of your methods, such as "getter" or "setter",
and which you can then specify in the outline view).

At any rate, just because you start using annotations doesn't mean you can't
keep starting your test method names with "test".


> The strength of your conviction in this area is causing me to
> wonder. Am I the only Java "guy" that finds benefit (on a fifteen
> developer project on two continents) in having a test method begin
> with he word "test" - or, a callback method begin with "pre"
> or "post" - or, a transparent persistence registration begin
> with "register"???


No, you're not. Quite a few TestNG users keep using "test", and that's
fine.

I'm not trying to convince anyone to abandon this idea, but I do want to
make a few points regarding the adequacy of using annotations in the testing
area, because I think they are a perfect tool for this job.

> Following your logic, shouldn't you rename testFoo() to ignoreFoo () then?
> >
>
> Sure. Except for the fact that "test" is a long-term perscription
> and "ignore" is (presumably) transitory. The nuances around which
> capability is appropriatly declared and which capability is
> appropriately inherited are more subtle than a verb study.
>
> In this case, "ignore" is a contextual assignment. It might
> mean, "ignore until I get this test method working". Whereas "test"
> means "always test" unless declared otherwise. "Ignore" is
> (conceptual) override of "test". They are not peers - so, a
> different stylistic implementation might be warranted.


Since we're talking stylistic issues here, I would point out that @Ignore is
a very poor choice for this purpose, since it doesn't say much about "ignore
what?". Or, in this case, "ignored by what?".

The equivalent in TestNG is an attribute: @Test(enabled = false), which
makes more sense in my opinion. An even better choice is to put the method
in an ignored group (@Test(groups = {"ignored"}) and then exclude that group
from your runs. The benefit of this approach is that the HTML reports list
all the groups that have been included and excluded, so it's very easy to
get a quick list of all the methods currently being ignored.

--
Cédric
